Name: -1_usc_university_department_officials
Representative_Docs: ['USC cutting 259 jobs as it tackles rising $230 million deficit The University of Southern California began cutting 259 jobs on Friday as it tackles a rising operating deficit of more than $230 million Since July 9, USC has laid off ‚Äî or is in the process of terminating ‚Äî 975 people throughout the university system‚Äôs nearly 24,600 faculty and staff. That tally doesn‚Äôt include 9,185 student workers. The university is ‚Äúreducing and reorganizing its workforce due to cutbacks in funding and necessary budget reductions,‚Äù wrote Melissa Gerdes-Leonard, associate vice president of client services with USC‚Äôs human resources department, in an Oct. 27 letter filed with the state‚Äôs Employment Development Department. Also see: USC won‚Äôt sign Trump compact on federal funding The latest round of layoffs are happening at USC‚Äôs University Park, a leafy 229-acre main campus for the institution‚Äôs academic schools and residential buildings near Exposition Park in downtown Los Angeles. After the cuts are completed Dec. 31, USC will have shed 616 people on its main campus, or two-thirds of the workforce laid off to date. Some of the positions cut include a marketing director, procurement specialist, research administrator, office managers, library supervisor, event', 'USC cutting 259 staff members to tackle rising $230 million deficit The University of Southern California began cutting 259 jobs on Friday as it tackles a rising operating deficit of more than $230 million Since July 9, USC has laid off ‚Äî or is in the process of terminating ‚Äî 975 people throughout the university system‚Äôs nearly 24,600 faculty and staff. That tally doesn‚Äôt include 9,185 student workers. The university is ‚Äúreducing and reorganizing its workforce due to cutbacks in funding and necessary budget reductions,‚Äù wrote Melissa Gerdes-Leonard, associate vice president of client services with USC‚Äôs human resources department, in an Oct. 27 letter filed with the state‚Äôs Employment Development Department. Also see: USC won‚Äôt sign Trump compact on federal funding The latest round of layoffs are happening at USC‚Äôs University Park, a leafy 229-acre main campus for the institution‚Äôs academic schools and residential buildings near Exposition Park in downtown Los Angeles. After the cuts are completed Dec. 31, USC will have shed 616 people on its main campus, or two-thirds of the workforce laid off to date. Some of the positions cut include a marketing director, procurement specialist, research administrator, office managers, library supervisor, event', "Inagawa helps pace Drake in 24-19 win over Butler to stay perfect in Pioneer Football League INDIANAPOLIS (AP) ‚Äî Logan Inagawa threw for 244 yards and a touchdown and Drake remained unbeaten in the Pioneer Football League by beating Butler 24-19 on Saturday. Drake's Isaiah Bragg returned the opening kickoff 32 yards to the Drake 34. On the first play from scrimmage, Nick Herman took the handoff and ran 66 yards to the end zone for a 7-0 Drake (6-2, 5-0) lead. Javascript is required for you to be able to read premium content. Name: 1_basketball_championship_offense_coach
Representative_Docs: ["Strong first half is enough for Indiana to topple Chicago State Lamar Wilkerson scored a game-high 21 points Saturday and Indiana made 14 of its 15 3-pointers in the first half of a 78-58 nonconference home win over Chicago State in Bloomington. Reed Bailey came off the bench to add 17 points and eight rebounds, while Nick Dorn contributed 15 points on 5-of-11 shooting from the 3-point line. The Hoosiers (9-3) drew assists on all but two of their 26 field goals, with Conor Enright dishing out seven and Wilkerson handing out six. Different people are pointing at various things as the cause or causes of the Golden State Warriors\' struggles this season. Some say it\'s because they don\'t have a consistent second option behind Steph Curry. Others say it\'s because their young guys have not progressed as expected. While some believe it\'s Steve Kerr\'s coaching. Former Miami Heat captain Udonis Haslem thinks that the Dubs\' issues are rooted in the fact that they did not get what they were supposed to receive last offseason. Just click ‚ÄúGift this Article‚Äù on this page, then copy the link or enter their email. Gifts are exclusive to subscribers, reset monthly, and each article can be redeemed once. The Tennessee Volunteers had a disappointing season after making their first College Football Playoff in 2024. The Volunteers, under the leadership of head coach Josh Heupel, finished the 2025 season with an 8-5 record. That was after being ranked as high as No. 11 in the country. However, the team struggled down the stretch, losing four of its final seven games. As a result, it is now focused on building a championship contender for the upcoming season. Name: 2_friendship_parents_husband_friends
Representative_Docs: ['Asking Eric: I‚Äôm annoyed that friend, IRL, never comments or ‚Äòlikes‚Äô my online posts Dear Eric: I have a friend I‚Äôve known for four years. We all live in a 55+ community and have moved here from different areas of the country. We are a group of women who get together on a regular basis for outings. Over the past couple of months, I feel somewhat left out because of a couple of events I wasn‚Äôt included in. But what I‚Äôm trying to understand is why does she not ‚Äúlike‚Äù or comment on any of my Facebook posts when she‚Äôs all over everyone else‚Äôs with supportive and loving comments? Again, this is so silly, but I can‚Äôt help wondering why. When I look back at my posts, I noticed she has never acknowledged any of them, even for my birthday. We are still friends, we work with the same fundraising group, have dinner at each other‚Äôs house and get invited to the same events. This Facebook thing has got me confused and I don‚Äôt know what kind of friend she is so I‚Äôm getting uncomfortable around her. So now, what am I doing? Ignoring her posts, which makes me feel so stupid and juvenile. If I wasn‚Äôt part of this group, which I really like, I wouldn‚Äôt bother with her. Can you shed any light on her mindset? It‚Äôs really got me confused. ‚Äì Friend Request Dear Friend: Even though social', 'Asking Eric: After 6 years sober, man is frustrated by his family‚Äôs hold on their hurt and distrust Dear Eric: I‚Äôve just turned 40 this past year. The last 15 years I was in a horrible drug addiction. I lied and hurt and did terrible things to a lot of people, especially my family. About eight years ago they officially disowned me. Understandable. I‚Äôve cleaned up and got my act together six years ago. At first, I tried to force my way back into their lives, which all refuted. I lashed out, said horrible things and stopped trying to be in their lives. My mom will stop by on my birthday for 10 minutes or so and drop a card off at Christmas. As for my two older brothers and my father, it‚Äôs radio silence. I guess what I‚Äôm asking is, what do I do to fix this and fast, as I said I‚Äôve turned 40 this year, my parents are both 70. Time is running out, and I couldn‚Äôt imagine living my life without some kind of acceptance from my father. Or knowing he did or does love me. My heart breaks at the thought, but this is a real pickle. How can I fix a problem when the ones I need to fix it with won‚Äôt talk to me? Do I just keep ignoring their existence and put on this fa√ßade that I don‚Äôt care to my wife and 4-year-old son? What picture am I painting to my son, as he‚Äôs been guilty by association yo', 'Asking Eric: Can mom work through tension in son‚Äôs relationship with dad so they can celebrate special birthday? Dear Eric: My son is turning 40 on December 22. My husband and I are at a quandary as to how to celebrate him. There have been issues between my husband and him over things from his childhood. We did a special trip for his older brother when he turned 40 and would like to do something special for this son‚Äôs 40th as well. Our daughter-in-law has made special plans for him and we are not included. I understand that, but I need some ideas as to how to celebrate this extra special year without rocking the boat. I love my son with all my heart, as I do all my children, and want his 40th birthday to be memorable in a positive way. Any suggestions? ‚Äì Mom Who Wants to Celebrate Dear Mom: The issues your son and your husband are having may be an obstacle, but they aren‚Äôt insurmountable. And the thing that can get them on the path to resolution is the same thing that can get you answers about how to celebrate your son: open communication. It‚Äôs not within your purview to try to fix things between them, but you have your own relationship with your son and so I‚Äôd encourage you to reach out and tell him what you told me: you want to celebrate him, you know things are difficult, and you‚Äôre lookin']

Name: 3_surgical_surgery_hospital_patients
Representative_Docs: ['VIDEO: $5.5M robotic surgery system arrives at Surrey Memorial Hospital Published 12:10 pm Tuesday, January 27, 2026 By Anna Burns The da Vinci Xi System has been unpacked and calibrated and is being held in a temporary location until its permanent location is finished. Fraser Health said that it expects it to ‚Äúgo-live‚Äù later in the spring. (Fraser Health/ Contributed to Surrey Now-Leader) Health care workers pose in front of the da Vinci Xi System. (Fraser Health/ Contributed to Surrey Now-Leader) Surrey Memorial Hospital is one step closer to providing robotic-assisted surgery with the arrival of the da Vinci Xi Robotic Surgery system. It is expected to be used in surgeries in the spring. ‚ÄúWith the aid of the da Vinci Xi system, we can expand minimally invasive thoracic and foregut surgery, and we can do operations with greater precision and accuracy,‚Äù says Dr Ahmad Ashrafi, regional division head and chief of thoracic surgery for Fraser Health. ‚ÄúPatients may experience quicker recovery times, and we can carry out more complex procedures right here in Surrey, using minimally invasive techniques. Name: 4_hospital_nursing_hospitals_patients
Representative_Docs: ['HNL Lab Medicine Brings Escape Room Fun to Hospital Education ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 10, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- HNL Lab Medicine is transforming hospital training by turning mandatory education into an adventure. To strengthen the collaboration between laboratory and nursing teams, HNL Lab Medicine\'s Clinical Hospital Advisors have introduced an innovative "escape room"‚Äìstyle educational game that turns essential lab‚Äêrelated lessons into an interactive experience. The escape room begins with a familiar challenge: how to avoid getting a phone call from the lab about a rejected sample. From there, nurses progress through a series of puzzles based on real‚Äêworld scenarios, selecting properly filled blood culture bottles; answering type & screen questions; identifying best practices to prevent clotted or hemolyzed samples; ordering laboratory tubes correctly, and collecting laboratory tubes in the correct order of draw. Each correct answer provides a key or code to unlock the next stage, ultimately leading to a prize. The activity takes less than ten minutes per nurse, no longer than a standard training session, but delivers far more excitement and engagement. The format encourages problem‚Äêsolving, sparks conversation, and helps key lessons stick. "Ou', 'HNL Lab Medicine Brings Escape Room Fun to Hospital Education ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 10, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- HNL Lab Medicine is transforming hospital training by turning mandatory education into an adventure. Name: 5_pigment_fabric_glow_colours
Representative_Docs: ['The darkest fabric ever made is now a dress There is black, and then there is ultrablack. The shade defined as a black that reflects less than 0.5 percent of the light that hits it, is used on everything from telescopes to cameras. This uniquely dark color is not easy to produce and may appear less black when it is viewed at an angle. To find a better way to reproduce this cool color, a team at Cornell University looked to nature. Specifically, a bird called the magnificent riflebird. The result is the darkest known fabric ever created and it is detailed in a study recently published in the journal Nature Communications. The magnificent riflebird is a large songbird and member of the bird-of-paradise family found in New Guinea and Australia. Male riflebirds are almost completely black, with a green and blue metallic sheen on their belly, throat, and crown feathers. With the help of Mary M. Ferraro and Vanya Rohwer from the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, the team studied the riflebird‚Äôs black feathers. Their plumage comes from melanin pigment paired with tightly bunched filaments called barbules that deflect light inward. This combination of pigment barbules means that the feathers absorb nearly all the light that hits it, makin', 'The darkest fabric ever made is now a dress Get the Popular Science daily newsletterüí° Breakthroughs, discoveries, and DIY tips sent every weekday. Name: 6_immigration_britain_immigrants_societal
Representative_Docs: ['‚ÄòUK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US‚Äô People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. The findings are said to show that a common narrative about Britain being more socially liberal than America does not ring true across all issues. The National Centre for Social Research also found Reform UK voters in Britain were more likely than supporters of President Donald Trump in the US to say immigrants living in their country without permission should not be allowed to stay. While seven in 10 supporters of Mr Trump felt this way, the figure was almost eight in 10 (79%) among Reform followers. The researchers said they wanted to ‚Äúbetter understand how public attitudes in the UK compare with those in the US, and the extent of polarisation in the two countries‚Äù. Their survey found 42% of people in the UK think there should be legal efforts to deport immigrants living here without permission, compared with just a third (33%) in the US. While almost two-thirds (64%) of respondents in the US felt diversity strengthens society, only around half (49%) of the UK public agreed. Proportions were similar when', '‚ÄòUK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US‚Äô People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. Name: 7_museum_egypt_egyptian_world largest
Representative_Docs: ["Egypt unveils the world's largest museum dedicated to a single civilization Egypt is inaugurating on Saturday the Grand Egyptian Museum, two decades in the making, with the aim of drawing more visitors to revitalize the country's tourist industry. Located just outside Cairo on the Giza Plateau which also includes the three pyramids and the Sphinx, the museum will be the world‚Äôs largest dedicated to a single civilization. It will display over 50,000 artifacts detailing life in ancient Egypt. World leaders, including monarchs, heads of states and governments, are set to attend the grand opening ceremony, according to the Egyptian presidency which touted the museum as ‚Äúan exceptional event in the history of human culture and civilization.‚Äù The museum is one of the megaprojects championed by President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi since he took office in 2014. He has embarked on massive investments in infrastructure with the aim of reviving an economy weakened by decades of stagnation and battered by the unrest that followed the 2011 Arab Spring uprising. Preparations for the grand reveal have been shrouded in secrecy. The museum, which was opened for limited visits in recent years, has been closed for the past two weeks. The government has revamped the areas around t", "Egypt unveils the world's largest museum dedicated to a single civilization CAIRO (AP) ‚Äî Egypt is inaugurating on Saturday the Grand Egyptian Museum, two decades in the making, with the aim of drawing more visitors to revitalize the country's tourist industry. Located just outside Cairo on the Giza Plateau which also includes the three pyramids and the Sphinx, the museum will be the world‚Äôs largest dedicated to a single civilization. It will display over 50,000 artifacts detailing life in ancient Egypt. World leaders, including monarchs, heads of states and governments, are set to attend the grand opening ceremony, according to the Egyptian presidency which touted the museum as ‚Äúan exceptional event in the history of human culture and civilization.‚Äù The museum is one of the megaprojects championed by President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi since he took office in 2014. He has embarked on massive investments in infrastructure with the aim of reviving an economy weakened by decades of stagnation and battered by the unrest that followed the 2011 Arab Spring uprising. Preparations for the grand reveal have been shrouded in secrecy. The museum, which was opened for limited visits in recent years, has been closed for the past two weeks. Representative_Docs: ['Dairy Queen brings Taylor and Swift to the Super Bowl 2026 with this promotion With the arrival of Super Bowl LX, more and more brands are joining the celebration of this sporting event with advertising campaigns and attractive offers for their customers. One of them is Dairy Queen, which has decided to ‚Äúbring‚Äù Taylor and Swift to the halftime show‚Ä¶ no, not the pop star, but two football players who come together in a new promotion from the franchise. Here‚Äôs what it‚Äôs all about. Dairy Queen decided to take advantage of that buzz with a clever campaign, bringing together football players Tyrod Taylor and D‚ÄôAndre Swift, whose last names form the name of the pop star. ALSO READ Paris Baguette Launches Menu and Special Deals for Football Season and the Super Bowl: What‚Äôs Included The players are promoting the brand‚Äôs new Chicken Strip Party Platters, which you can get for free through a simple promotion: tag your game-day buddy and you‚Äôll have the chance to win one of 60 Chicken Str', "THE THINK PINK GALA DEBUTS MARCH 14TH 2026 AT THE PLAZA WITH BERNADETTE PETERS AND A MICHELIN-STARRED CULINARY EXPERIENCE A landmark night of glamour, generosity, and world-class artistry in support of breast cancer patients, survivors, and families NEW YORK, Jan. 12, 2026 /PRNewswire/ -- The Think Pink Gala will debut on Saturday, March 14th, 2026, at the iconic Plaza Hotel, marking a premier cultural milestone in the New York philanthropic season. This inaugural evening unites world-class artistry with culinary excellence to mark United Breast Cancer Foundation's landmark 25th anniversary of life-changing support. The evening features Broadway legend and three-time Tony Award winner Bernadette Peters, two-time Tony Award winner Christine Ebersole, whose legendary career continues to define the height of American musical theater and screen, and Melissa Errico, celebrated as one of the most iconic leading ladies of musical theater. The program highlights the work of Emmy and Grammy nominated conductor, composer, and musical director Judith Clurman, who leads Judith Clurman's Essential Voices USA, an acclaimed, award-winning choral ensemble and one of New York's preeminent vocal groups. The stage also features Simone Dinnerstein, a Diapason d'Or winner with fifteen number-one Billboard Classical albums", "THE THINK PINK GALA DEBUTS MARCH 14TH 2026 AT THE PLAZA WITH BERNADETTE PETERS AND A MICHELIN-STARRED CULINARY EXPERIENCE A landmark night of glamour, generosity, and world-class artistry in support of breast cancer patients, survivors, and families NEW YORK, Jan. 12, 2026 /PRNewswire/ -- The Think Pink Gala will debut on Saturday, March 14th, 2026, at the iconic Plaza Hotel, marking a premier cultural milestone in the New York philanthropic season. In an interview, Fraser discusses his life since the Oscar win, his eye-opening experiences in Japan and what returning to the ‚ÄúMummy‚Äù series means to him. Name: 10_central bank_federal reserve_florence_near term
Representative_Docs: ['Florence Press Conference Confirms ECB Remains Comfortable in Its Good Place Even a change of scenery has done nothing to change the European Central Bank‚Äôs current wait-and-see stance. Florence, where the ECB met today for its only annual meeting outside of Frankfurt, is apparently also this ‚Äôgood place‚Äô, the central bank‚Äôs well-known pseudonym for comfortably keeping interest rates on hold. ECB President Christine Lagarde even called it a ‚Äòmagnificent‚Äô place ‚Äì Florence, that is, not rates. The comments at the press conference confirmed once again that the ECB has no intention to leave its ‚Äògood place‚Äô any time soon. We had feared a rather uneventful press conference. What should we say? We hate to be right‚Ä¶ Anyhow, here are a few interesting remarks made by Lagarde: On the ECB‚Äôs risk assessment, the introductory statement had the most remarkable change compared with September. Last month, the ECB had still talked about risks to the growth outlook that had become ‚Äúmore balanced‚Äù; today, it refrained from qualifying any balance of risk. Instead, the central bank had a somewhat more extensive list of upside and downside risks to the growth outlook. Lagarde even said that some of the downside risks had abated.
